values.description:
Fix issue #!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1197/dartjoint-getforcetorque-returns-wrong . 

Added an additional check in `REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame` to test the proper handling of the joint frame-child link frame offset. 

The issue was that the force/torque was expressed in the joint orientation frame instead of the child frame orientation frame. 

Additional testing showed that the `getForceTorque` method has still several bugs, but I will try to replicate them in a more scalable test case that will test force torque readings in `revolute`, `prismatic` and eventually `fixed` joints.
values.title: Solve failure of REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame for DART

summary.raw:
Fix issue #!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1197/dartjoint-getforcetorque-returns-wrong . 

Added an additional check in `REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame` to test the proper handling of the joint frame-child link frame offset. 

The issue was that the force/torque was expressed in the joint orientation frame instead of the child frame orientation frame. 

Additional testing showed that the `getForceTorque` method has still several bugs, but I will try to replicate them in a more scalable test case that will test force torque readings in `revolute`, `prismatic` and eventually `fixed` joints.
summary.html:
Fix issue #!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1197/dartjoint-getforcetorque-returns-wrong .

Added an additional check in REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame to test the proper handling of the joint frame-child link frame offset.

The issue was that the force/torque was expressed in the joint orientation frame instead of the child frame orientation frame.

Additional testing showed that the getForceTorque method has still several bugs, but I will try to replicate them in a more scalable test case that will test force torque readings in revolute, prismatic and eventually fixed joints.

values.description:
This pull request addresses issues:

issue #1572 Failure to compile/run without uuid-dev. The uuid-dev library was added to CMake as an optional library. The changes were copied from the GTS triangulation library support.

issue #1574 Crashes when REST server connection fails. An error message is now showed to the user instead. Also, to avoid too many error messages, the user can now "logout" from the REST server. REST messages are queued when they cannot be served.

Jenkins reported 1 unrelated error:
http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/184
values.title: Mentor 2 MOOC related bug fixes and enhancements

summary.raw:
This pull request addresses issues:

issue #1572 Failure to compile/run without uuid-dev. The uuid-dev library was added to CMake as an optional library. The changes were copied from the GTS triangulation library support.

issue #1574 Crashes when REST server connection fails. An error message is now showed to the user instead. Also, to avoid too many error messages, the user can now "logout" from the REST server. REST messages are queued when they cannot be served.

Jenkins reported 1 unrelated error:
http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/184
summary.html:
This pull request addresses issues:

issue #1572 Failure to compile/run without uuid-dev. The uuid-dev library was added to CMake as an optional library. The changes were copied from the GTS triangulation library support.

issue #1574 Crashes when REST server connection fails. An error message is now showed to the user instead. Also, to avoid too many error messages, the user can now "logout" from the REST server. REST messages are queued when they cannot be served.

Jenkins reported 1 unrelated error: http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/184

values.description:
Bullet 2.83 was [recently released](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/releases/tag/2.83). It has new features and also API changes. This pull request includes:

* Fix for an API change that prevents BulletHinge2Joint.cc from compiling successfully
* Use new `btHingeAccumulatedAngleConstraint` which provides wrapped angles for hinge joint (#1074). Note that joint limits larger than one revolution are not yet support.
* Also a minor change to simbody search logic that is required to build against simbody master branch.

This should do no harm to systems using bullet 2.82, but fix compilation and partially address #1074 for systems using bullet 2.83.

* [jenkins trusty nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/132/) is clean
* [coverage](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/102/) is clean
* [no-gpu build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/187/) is clean
values.title: Support bullet 2.83

values.description:
Pull request  #1654 broke rendering. It changed WindowManger.cc:90

from: `params["externalGLControl"] = true;`

to: `params["externalGLControl"] = "true";`

The `from:` line was actually translated to `false` by Ogre, whereas the `to:` line was translate to `true` by Ogre.

So, `"false"` is the correct value for linux. It may be the incorrect value for Windows, but I'll handle that case in a separate pull request.
values.title: Fix gazebo rendering

summary.raw:
Pull request  #1654 broke rendering. It changed WindowManger.cc:90

from: `params["externalGLControl"] = true;`

to: `params["externalGLControl"] = "true";`

The `from:` line was actually translated to `false` by Ogre, whereas the `to:` line was translate to `true` by Ogre.

So, `"false"` is the correct value for linux. It may be the incorrect value for Windows, but I'll handle that case in a separate pull request.
summary.html:
Pull request #1654 broke rendering. It changed WindowManger.cc:90

from: params["externalGLControl"] = true;

to: params["externalGLControl"] = "true";

The from: line was actually translated to false by Ogre, whereas the to: line was translate to true by Ogre.

So, "false" is the correct value for linux. It may be the incorrect value for Windows, but I'll handle that case in a separate pull request.

values.description:
Redo of pull request #1656 with a fix for 2.83 in cdbe461.

Bullet 2.83 was [recently released](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/releases/tag/2.83). It has new features and also API changes. This pull request includes:

* Fix for an API change that prevents BulletHinge2Joint.cc from compiling successfully
* Use new `btHingeAccumulatedAngleConstraint` which provides wrapped angles for hinge joint (#1074). Note that joint limits larger than one revolution are not yet support.
* Also a minor change to simbody search logic that is required to build against simbody master branch.

This should do no harm to systems using bullet 2.82, but fix compilation and partially address #1074 for systems using bullet 2.83.

* [no-gpu build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/191/) is clean
* [trusty nvidia build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/144/) is clean
values.title: Support bullet 2.83

* Use new `btHingeAccumulatedAngleConstraint` which provides wrapped angles for hinge joint (#1074). Note that joint limits larger than one revolution are not yet support.
* Also a minor change to simbody search logic that is required to build against simbody master branch.

This should do no harm to systems using bullet 2.82, but fix compilation and partially address #1074 for systems using bullet 2.83.

values.description:
This mainly try to partially fix the problem of exporting gazebo libraries in the corresponding order depending on the internal interdependencies.

Please note that we are still affected by the circular dependency problem (issue #1516) but that is out of the scope of this PR. I have modified the test library depedencies in this PR, but @scpeters has a nicer pull request to completely improve the situation after this PR, so consider this as a partial fix too.
values.title: Fix order of exported libraries (issue #1568)

summary.raw:
This mainly try to partially fix the problem of exporting gazebo libraries in the corresponding order depending on the internal interdependencies.

Please note that we are still affected by the circular dependency problem (issue #1516) but that is out of the scope of this PR. I have modified the test library depedencies in this PR, but @scpeters has a nicer pull request to completely improve the situation after this PR, so consider this as a partial fix too.
summary.html:
This mainly try to partially fix the problem of exporting gazebo libraries in the corresponding order depending on the internal interdependencies.

Please note that we are still affected by the circular dependency problem (issue #1516) but that is out of the scope of this PR. I have modified the test library depedencies in this PR, but @scpeters has a nicer pull request to completely improve the situation after this PR, so consider this as a partial fix too.

values.description:
This implements the idea of merging sensors and physics libraries into one, since currently they are mutually dependent, which generates a circular linking problem and creates all kind of problems for third party software develop on to of gazebo.

Should be a workaround for issues #1516 and #1597.
values.title: Merge sensors and physics in one lib to avoid cyclic linking (issue #1516)

summary.raw:
This implements the idea of merging sensors and physics libraries into one, since currently they are mutually dependent, which generates a circular linking problem and creates all kind of problems for third party software develop on to of gazebo.

Should be a workaround for issues #1516 and #1597.
summary.html:
This implements the idea of merging sensors and physics libraries into one, since currently they are mutually dependent, which generates a circular linking problem and creates all kind of problems for third party software develop on to of gazebo.

Should be a workaround for issues #1516 and #1597.

values.reason: Nate prefers not to go with this approach

values.description:
Another part of the ROCON work, due this week.

In this pull request:

1. Added Meta information to Visual protobuf messages.

1. Code to read meta information from SDF and add to visual messages.

1. Small change to `1208_world_plugin_init` to improve test stability. See [this build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/226/testReport/junit/(root)/Issue1208Test/Reset/)

1. Example world (`shapes_layers.world`) that uses visual meta information.

The graphical interface to layers is very minimal right now. Additional features (such as adding layers via the GUI) will be added in the near future.

[Nvidia clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/174)
values.title: Use Meta information in SDF visuals in gzclient

  2. Code to read meta information from SDF and add to visual messages.

  3. Small change to 1208_world_plugin_init to improve test stability. See this build

The graphical interface to layers is very minimal right now. Additional features (such as adding layers via the GUI) will be added in the near future.

values.description:
@\_jrivero\_  I removed a bit of the boost configuration in `SearchForStuff.cmake`, and used `add_definitions(-DBOOST_ALL_DYN_LINK)` in `GazeboUtils.cmake`. It all builds and runs on Windows. What do you think?

[Nvidia is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/176/)

[No gpu looks good](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/234/)

values.description:
I don't know why this is a problem, but it seems to fix it. Resolves #1590. I think this should not affect ABI since this is a private function.

Thanks to @bchretien for the report and @v01d for the suggested fix.

This affects Arch Linux and all versions of gazebo using homebrew OS X, which recently upgraded boost 1.58. I will eventually merge this forward to gazebo5 and default.
values.title: Remove & from TimePanel::OnFullScreen argument to fix boost 1.58 build

values.description:
With a more recent cmake, one of the standalone examples gives a warning that `test` shouldn't be used as a cmake target. This just changes it to `test_example`:
~~~
CMake Warning (dev) at CMakeLists.txt:21 (add_executable):
  Policy CMP0037 is not set: Target names should not be reserved and should
  match a validity pattern.  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0037" for policy
  details.  Use the cmake_policy command to set the policy and suppress this
  warning.

  The target name "test" is reserved or not valid for certain CMake features,
  such as generator expressions, and may result in undefined behavior.
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.

~~~
values.title: Fix cmake warning about having a target named test

values.description:
This pull request makes sure `SelectionObj` destroys all objects and nodes attached to it when it is terminated. If they're not destroyed, Ogre crashes if someone tries to create a new visual with the same name as the deleted one.

This is needed to enable mouse manipulation of `ApplyWrenchVisual`.
values.title: Fix finishing SelectionObj, with test

summary.raw:
This pull request makes sure `SelectionObj` destroys all objects and nodes attached to it when it is terminated. If they're not destroyed, Ogre crashes if someone tries to create a new visual with the same name as the deleted one.

This is needed to enable mouse manipulation of `ApplyWrenchVisual`.
summary.html:
This pull request makes sure SelectionObj destroys all objects and nodes attached to it when it is terminated. If they're not destroyed, Ogre crashes if someone tries to create a new visual with the same name as the deleted one.

This is needed to enable mouse manipulation of ApplyWrenchVisual.

values.description:
There is a bug in bullet 2.82 related to the `maxLinMotorForce` parameter that was fixed in bullet 2.83 (see pull request #1452 and the [upstream issue](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/pull/328)). This adds ifdef's so that the workaround is not required if bullet 2.83 is being used.

Also, there is a slight modification of the hinge joint angle wrapping test in `INTEGRATION_joint_revolute` that reduces the console output during failures and allows much of the test to be run for bullet 2.82.

Finally, I backport a stability improvement to the `REGRESSION_1208_world_plugin_init` test.

* [jenkins nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/190/) clean
* [jenkins no-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/254/) clean

UPDATE:

* 23d099c8f10a: fix some clang warnings on OS X
values.title: Fix BulletSliderJoint friction for bullet 2.83

summary.raw:
There is a bug in bullet 2.82 related to the `maxLinMotorForce` parameter that was fixed in bullet 2.83 (see pull request #1452 and the [upstream issue](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/pull/328)). This adds ifdef's so that the workaround is not required if bullet 2.83 is being used.

Also, there is a slight modification of the hinge joint angle wrapping test in `INTEGRATION_joint_revolute` that reduces the console output during failures and allows much of the test to be run for bullet 2.82.

Finally, I backport a stability improvement to the `REGRESSION_1208_world_plugin_init` test.

summary.html:
There is a bug in bullet 2.82 related to the maxLinMotorForce parameter that was fixed in bullet 2.83 (see pull request #1452 and the upstream issue). This adds ifdef's so that the workaround is not required if bullet 2.83 is being used.

Also, there is a slight modification of the hinge joint angle wrapping test in INTEGRATION_joint_revolute that reduces the console output during failures and allows much of the test to be run for bullet 2.82.

Finally, I backport a stability improvement to the REGRESSION_1208_world_plugin_init test.

  • jenkins nvidia clean
  • jenkins no-gpu clean

UPDATE:

  • 23d099c8f10a: fix some clang warnings on OS X

values.description:
For the glory, here is the last pull request to make Gazebo work on Windows.

1. Read the comments in `GLWidget`, `WindowManager`, and `RenderEngine` to get an idea of the order of operations that is necessary for rendering on Mac, Windows, and Linux.

1. GLWidget no longer listens to the `OnCreateScene` event. Previously, the `RenderWidget` would trigger the `createScene` event right after the `GLWidget` was constructed. Now scene creation has been moved directly into GLWidget's constructor.

1. Casting Window ID's to specific types in `GLWidget::GetOgreHandle` is extremely important for Windows and Linux. Mac doesn't seem to care that much.

1. Added a test to `MainWindow_TEST` that checks setting the UserCamera via SDF. Added this test because Gazebo could (and did) crash on start if the order of operations in `GLWidget`, `MainWindow`, and `RenderEngine` is not correct. Take this as a hint to try out multiple worlds, configurations, etc.

1. Fixed the `MainWindow_TEST` by disabling `g_stepAct` when it's created in `MainWindow::CreateActions`, and also removing what seems to be an extraneous call to `TimePanel::OnPlayActionChanged` in `TimePanel::TimePanel`.

1. `gzserver` will crash on Windows if `ODELink` tries to access the `dirtyPoses` list directly. A helper function has been added, which makes the code a bit cleaner at the cost of having an extra function call. The performance impact should be minimal, and I'm running a test now to check. This segfault is also why I'd like to see if there is a memory leak/overwrite somewhere in the code.


[Video proof, or it didn't happen](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tNnFxSRQmi8)

[no gpu is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/258/)

[homebrew looks ok](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/180/)

[nvidia clean (except for the render widget test that was fixed)](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/194/)
values.title: Windows final

summary.raw:
For the glory, here is the last pull request to make Gazebo work on Windows.

1. Read the comments in `GLWidget`, `WindowManager`, and `RenderEngine` to get an idea of the order of operations that is necessary for rendering on Mac, Windows, and Linux.

1. GLWidget no longer listens to the `OnCreateScene` event. Previously, the `RenderWidget` would trigger the `createScene` event right after the `GLWidget` was constructed. Now scene creation has been moved directly into GLWidget's constructor.

1. Casting Window ID's to specific types in `GLWidget::GetOgreHandle` is extremely important for Windows and Linux. Mac doesn't seem to care that much.

1. Added a test to `MainWindow_TEST` that checks setting the UserCamera via SDF. Added this test because Gazebo could (and did) crash on start if the order of operations in `GLWidget`, `MainWindow`, and `RenderEngine` is not correct. Take this as a hint to try out multiple worlds, configurations, etc.

1. Fixed the `MainWindow_TEST` by disabling `g_stepAct` when it's created in `MainWindow::CreateActions`, and also removing what seems to be an extraneous call to `TimePanel::OnPlayActionChanged` in `TimePanel::TimePanel`.

1. `gzserver` will crash on Windows if `ODELink` tries to access the `dirtyPoses` list directly. A helper function has been added, which makes the code a bit cleaner at the cost of having an extra function call. The performance impact should be minimal, and I'm running a test now to check. This segfault is also why I'd like to see if there is a memory leak/overwrite somewhere in the code.


[Video proof, or it didn't happen](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tNnFxSRQmi8)

[no gpu is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/258/)

[homebrew looks ok](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/180/)

[nvidia clean (except for the render widget test that was fixed)](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/194/)
summary.html:
For the glory, here is the last pull request to make Gazebo work on Windows.

  1. Read the comments in GLWidget, WindowManager, and RenderEngine to get an idea of the order of operations that is necessary for rendering on Mac, Windows, and Linux.

  2. GLWidget no longer listens to the OnCreateScene event. Previously, the RenderWidget would trigger the createScene event right after the GLWidget was constructed. Now scene creation has been moved directly into GLWidget's constructor.

  3. Casting Window ID's to specific types in GLWidget::GetOgreHandle is extremely important for Windows and Linux. Mac doesn't seem to care that much.

  4. Added a test to MainWindow_TEST that checks setting the UserCamera via SDF. Added this test because Gazebo could (and did) crash on start if the order of operations in GLWidget, MainWindow, and RenderEngine is not correct. Take this as a hint to try out multiple worlds, configurations, etc.

  5. Fixed the MainWindow_TEST by disabling g_stepAct when it's created in MainWindow::CreateActions, and also removing what seems to be an extraneous call to TimePanel::OnPlayActionChanged in TimePanel::TimePanel.

  6. gzserver will crash on Windows if ODELink tries to access the dirtyPoses list directly. A helper function has been added, which makes the code a bit cleaner at the cost of having an extra function call. The performance impact should be minimal, and I'm running a test now to check. This segfault is also why I'd like to see if there is a memory leak/overwrite somewhere in the code.

Video proof, or it didn't happen

no gpu is clean

homebrew looks ok

nvidia clean (except for the render widget test that was fixed)

values.title: Found this bug while building in Profile mode.

values.description:
`common::Timer` returns the elapsed time between when the timer was started and when it was stopped (or the current time). This pull request gives `Timer` the option to be initialized as a "countdown" timer. A "countdown" timer has a `maxTime` variable representing the time that the `Timer` counts down from. It tracks the start and stop time, but returns the "elapsed" time as the time elapsed from the `maxTime`.

The countdown timer is now accessible through the `TimerGUIPlugin` by specifying a `countdown_time` in SDF:

```
<countdown_time>(seconds) (nanoseconds)</countdown_time>
```

You can test this pull request by enabling the `TimerGUIPlugin` overlay with this SDF block:

```
      <plugin name="TimerGUIPlugin" filename="libTimerGUIPlugin.so">
        <size>155 80</size>
        <start_stop_button>1</start_stop_button>
       <reset_button>1</reset_button>
        <topic>~/timer_control</topic>
        <countdown_time>60 1000</countdown_time>
      </plugin>
```
values.title: Add countdown feature to common::Timer, expose countdown to TimerGUIPlugin

summary.raw:
`common::Timer` returns the elapsed time between when the timer was started and when it was stopped (or the current time). This pull request gives `Timer` the option to be initialized as a "countdown" timer. A "countdown" timer has a `maxTime` variable representing the time that the `Timer` counts down from. It tracks the start and stop time, but returns the "elapsed" time as the time elapsed from the `maxTime`.

The countdown timer is now accessible through the `TimerGUIPlugin` by specifying a `countdown_time` in SDF:

```
<countdown_time>(seconds) (nanoseconds)</countdown_time>
```

You can test this pull request by enabling the `TimerGUIPlugin` overlay with this SDF block:

```
      <plugin name="TimerGUIPlugin" filename="libTimerGUIPlugin.so">
        <size>155 80</size>
        <start_stop_button>1</start_stop_button>
       <reset_button>1</reset_button>
        <topic>~/timer_control</topic>
        <countdown_time>60 1000</countdown_time>
      </plugin>
```
summary.html:
common::Timer returns the elapsed time between when the timer was started and when it was stopped (or the current time). This pull request gives Timer the option to be initialized as a "countdown" timer. A "countdown" timer has a maxTime variable representing the time that the Timer counts down from. It tracks the start and stop time, but returns the "elapsed" time as the time elapsed from the maxTime.

The countdown timer is now accessible through the TimerGUIPlugin by specifying a countdown_time in SDF:

<countdown_time>(seconds) (nanoseconds)</countdown_time>

You can test this pull request by enabling the TimerGUIPlugin overlay with this SDF block:

      <plugin name="TimerGUIPlugin" filename="libTimerGUIPlugin.so">
        <size>155 80</size>
        <start_stop_button>1</start_stop_button>
       <reset_button>1</reset_button>
        <topic>~/timer_control</topic>
        <countdown_time>60 1000</countdown_time>
      </plugin>

values.description:
Visualizing a hokuyo or pr2 on OS X causes gzclient to abort with an ogre assertion (#1608):
~~~
Assertion failed:
((min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) &&
 "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"), 
function setExtents, file /tmp/ogre-wLLoLh/ogre_src_v1-7-4/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h, line 252.
Abort trap: 6
~~~
The fix involves checking for infinite range values before setting rayFans points (see the `hitRange` variable). I also reduced the scope of some local variables in that function. Use the side-by-side diff viewer for better coloring of the changes.

* [trusty nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/199/) is happy
values.title: Fix LaserVisual on OSX (#1608)

summary.raw:
Visualizing a hokuyo or pr2 on OS X causes gzclient to abort with an ogre assertion (#1608):
~~~
Assertion failed:
((min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) &&
 "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"), 
function setExtents, file /tmp/ogre-wLLoLh/ogre_src_v1-7-4/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h, line 252.
Abort trap: 6
~~~
The fix involves checking for infinite range values before setting rayFans points (see the `hitRange` variable). I also reduced the scope of some local variables in that function. Use the side-by-side diff viewer for better coloring of the changes.

* [trusty nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/199/) is happy
summary.html:
Visualizing a hokuyo or pr2 on OS X causes gzclient to abort with an ogre assertion (#1608):

Assertion failed:
((min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) &&
 "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"), 
function setExtents, file /tmp/ogre-wLLoLh/ogre_src_v1-7-4/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h, line 252.
Abort trap: 6

The fix involves checking for infinite range values before setting rayFans points (see the hitRange variable). I also reduced the scope of some local variables in that function. Use the side-by-side diff viewer for better coloring of the changes.

  • trusty nvidia is happy

values.description:
![cessna_world.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3805120701-cessna_world.jpg)

Requires [this gazebo_models pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/144/).

All the wing parameters for the `LiftDragPlugin` were computed based on [this document](https://github.com/tridge/jsbsim/blob/master/aircraft/c172p/c172p.xml) and some custom graphs/equations. Ask me if you need access to it.

Elevator and ruddle data are not so evident to me. The following parameters for the elevator and ruddle elements should be reviewed by someone with better aeronautic knowledge than me: `cla`, `dsa`, `cma`, `alpha_stall`, `cla_stall`, `cda_stall`, `cma_stall`. 

For now, I used the same values included on the main wings.
values.title: Adding a world file with the Cessna model and the liftDrag plugin

values.reason: Not ready yet, making sure it flies

values.description:
Elevator and related events.

This expands upon the `events` in `plugins`. I added a new `OccupiedEvent` so that the `InRegionEvent` functionality does not change. The `InRegionEvent` checks for a single model in the region, while `OccupiedEvent` checks any non-static model.

The elevator works by putting an object in front of the doors.
values.title: Elevator plugin, Occupied sim event

values.title: Don't build gazebo executable on Windows for now, since it doesn't compile

values.description:
The default collide bitmask was 0x01. This is problematic because the number of bitmask choices are now severely limited.

**Example**

1. Object 1 should not collide with object 2.
2. Object 2 should not collide with object 1.
3. All other objects should collide with object 1 and object 2.

This configuration is impossible when "all other objects" have a default bitmask of 0x01, unless you somehow give new bitmasks to each object that is inserted.

**Solution**

Make the default collision bitmask the same as the ground plane (0xffff = 65535). This gives a lot more wiggle room to configure bitmasks.


[Updated tutorial](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/217)
values.title: Fix default collide bitmask

summary.raw:
The default collide bitmask was 0x01. This is problematic because the number of bitmask choices are now severely limited.

**Example**

1. Object 1 should not collide with object 2.
2. Object 2 should not collide with object 1.
3. All other objects should collide with object 1 and object 2.

This configuration is impossible when "all other objects" have a default bitmask of 0x01, unless you somehow give new bitmasks to each object that is inserted.

**Solution**

Make the default collision bitmask the same as the ground plane (0xffff = 65535). This gives a lot more wiggle room to configure bitmasks.


[Updated tutorial](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/217)
summary.html:
The default collide bitmask was 0x01. This is problematic because the number of bitmask choices are now severely limited.

Example

  1. Object 1 should not collide with object 2.
  2. Object 2 should not collide with object 1.
  3. All other objects should collide with object 1 and object 2.

This configuration is impossible when "all other objects" have a default bitmask of 0x01, unless you somehow give new bitmasks to each object that is inserted.

Solution

Make the default collision bitmask the same as the ground plane (0xffff = 65535). This gives a lot more wiggle room to configure bitmasks.

Updated tutorial

values.title: OSRF building world with functional elevator

values.description:
23 of the 29 plugin headers contain the `GAZEBO_VISIBLE` attribute, which exports the plugin's symbols to the shared library. This must have slipped for the other six libraries (`ActuatorPlugin`, `BuoyancyPlugin`, `HydraDemoPlugin`, `HydraPlugin`, `ImuSensorPlugin` and `LiftDragPlugin`). 

When this attribute is not specified, the shared libraries generated by G++ (version 4.8.2-19ubuntu1) do not contain symbols referring to the classes. However, when creating new plugins by subclassing any of these six, these symbol definitions are needed. Otherwise, `undefined symbol` errors are generated.
values.title: Export methods and constructors of these plugins to shared libraries.

summary.raw:
23 of the 29 plugin headers contain the `GAZEBO_VISIBLE` attribute, which exports the plugin's symbols to the shared library. This must have slipped for the other six libraries (`ActuatorPlugin`, `BuoyancyPlugin`, `HydraDemoPlugin`, `HydraPlugin`, `ImuSensorPlugin` and `LiftDragPlugin`). 

When this attribute is not specified, the shared libraries generated by G++ (version 4.8.2-19ubuntu1) do not contain symbols referring to the classes. However, when creating new plugins by subclassing any of these six, these symbol definitions are needed. Otherwise, `undefined symbol` errors are generated.
summary.html:
23 of the 29 plugin headers contain the GAZEBO_VISIBLE attribute, which exports the plugin's symbols to the shared library. This must have slipped for the other six libraries (ActuatorPlugin, BuoyancyPlugin, HydraDemoPlugin, HydraPlugin, ImuSensorPlugin and LiftDragPlugin).

When this attribute is not specified, the shared libraries generated by G++ (version 4.8.2-19ubuntu1) do not contain symbols referring to the classes. However, when creating new plugins by subclassing any of these six, these symbol definitions are needed. Otherwise, undefined symbol errors are generated.

values.description:
This pull requests introduces a lot of code for very little functionality: activating the dialog corresponding to the clicked visual. 

To test it, you'll need to have at least 2 `ApplyWrenchDialog`s open at the same time (for different links or the same link) and clicking on the orange visuals should focus its corresponding dialog.

Background: pull request #1506 was declined because it introduced mysterious crashes, so I've been dividing it into smaller PRs. So far, pull request #1600 and pull request #1619 have been merged.

Jenkins: http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/148/console
values.title: Apply Force/Torque dialog: Activate window when visual clicked
